title: Asymptotics for the reciprocal and shifted quotient of the partition function

sections.simplification of the sums s2â€‹(t)s_{2}:
Before we apply our summation tools to S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) we observe that the sum representation inÂ (4.15) can be rewritten in the form recall that Î±=Ï€6\alpha=\frac{\pi}{6}.
In the following we will focus on the inner sum which reads as Using the summation package Sigma (or alternatively, any other package, likeÂ , that can deal with the creative telescoping paradigmÂ  for hypergeometric products) one obtains the linear recurrence Next, we are interested in dâ€™Alembertian solutions of the found recurrence, i.e., in the set of all solutions that can be given in terms of indefinite nested sums defined over hypergeometric products. Using Sigma we find two linearly independent solutions of the homogeneous version of the recurrenceÂ (6.1). To this end, we apply a generalized versionÂ  of
PetkovÅ¡ekâ€™s Hyper algorithmÂ ; we remark that the bases âˆ’72âˆ’Ï€2+12â€‹36+Ï€2Ï€2\frac{-72-\pi^{2}+12\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}}{\pi^{2}} and âˆ’72+Ï€2+12â€‹36+Ï€2Ï€2-\frac{72+\pi^{2}+12\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}}{\pi^{2}}of the powers inÂ (6.2) are the roots of the characteristic polynomial that appears in the underlying algorithmÂ . In the next step, we can apply the algorithm given inÂ  to find the particular solution of the recurrenceÂ (6.1) in terms of an indefinite nested double sum over the powers given inÂ (6.2). Then a crucial step for further processing, i.e., for carrying out the estimates in SectionÂ 6.2, is the simplification of the found particular solution. Here again the summation package Sigma can assist; for a survey of the used telescoping algorithms we refer, e.g., toÂ 7. However, with the given limitations of the computer algebra system Mathematica, the underlying implementation does not work properly when dealing with algebraic elements such as 36+Ï€2\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}. To overcome this situation, we perform the substitution for a new variable bb; note that the inverse substitution is In this way, the technically challenging element 36+Ï€2\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}} vanishes; it simplifies to We remark that such rewritings (also called rationalizing transformations) appear frequently when dealing with nested integrals in the research area of elementary particle physics; for a survey and applications we refer toÂ 7. After this preprocessing step we continue with the sum representation where By construction, if we apply the substitutionÂ (6.5) to S~2â€‹(t)\tilde{S}_{2}(t) one gets S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) back. Repeating the above calculations in this new representation we obtain the improved recurrence We remark that the correctness of the recurrence can be verified by the summand recurrence (not printed here) that is provided by the creative telescoping method.
Solving this recurrence we get now the two linearly independent solutions of the homogeneous version; note that these solutions agree withÂ (6.2) with the substitutions inÂ (6.5), resp.Â (6.4). Most relevant, using Sigma the found particular solution can be simplified to the form for some rational functions R1â€‹(t,u)R_{1}(t,u), R2â€‹(t,u)R_{2}(t,u) and R3â€‹(t,u)R_{3}(t,u) in the variables b,u,tb,u,t. We remark that correctness of the computed solutions can be verified easily by plugging them into the recurrence, carrying out the shift operator on the indefinite nested sums and products, and by finally simplification by performing simple rational function arithmetic. In summary, using Sigma we found two linearly independent solutions of the homogeneous version together with the a particular solution P~â€‹(t,u)\tilde{P}(t,u) of the recurrence itself. Due to the linearly independence of the homogeneous solutions, there exist unique constants c1â€‹(t)c_{1}(t) and c2â€‹(t)c_{2}(t) (free of uu) such that holds for all nonnegative integers tt and uu with tâ‰¥2t\geq 2 and 1â‰¤uâ‰¤tâˆ’21\leq u\leq t-2.
To determine these cjâ€‹(t)c_{j}(t), we consider the two initial values T~â€‹(t,1)\tilde{T}(t,1) and T~â€‹(t,2)\tilde{T}(t,2) which can be simplified with the same technology as above (where tt has taken over the role of uu) to the form By setting u=1,2u=1,2 inÂ (6.6) and solving the underlying system we compute the c1â€‹(t)c_{1}(t) and c2â€‹(t)c_{2}(t) (which we do not print here) and
obtain the desired simplification Finally, we replace in the sum T~â€‹(t,u)\tilde{T}(t,u) by the right-hand side ofÂ (6.7) and apply the substitutionÂ (6.4). This yields an expression that agrees with S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) for all tâ‰¥2t\geq 2 from which one can read of the splittingsÂ (6.15)â€“(6.16) of S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) which in SectionÂ 6.2 are used to obtain the estimateÂ (4.29) in LemmaÂ 4.10. As indicated above, all calculations can be verified independently from the steps of their algorithmic derivations and thus lead to a rigorous proof for the correctness of the simplification. However, all the steps are tedious to handle manually.
To assist such calculations (that are similarly to those that we frequently tackle in particle physicsÂ ),
we provide besides Sigma the package EvaluateMultiSumsÂ 6 which contains all the experience of the Sigmaâ€“developer to carry out these calculations fully automatically. More precisely, after loading the packages

Using Sigma one obtains the recurrence with a right-hand side Râ€‹(t,u)R(t,u) represented in terms of indefinite nested sums too large for being printed here. Solving the homogeneous version of the recurrence gives the two solutions which are closely related to the solutionsÂ (6.2) when dealing with S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t). Indeed, the algorithmÂ  (and the generalized versionÂ  implemented in Sigma) asks again for the roots of the same polynomialÂ (6.3) that establishes the powers involving the algebraic element
36+Ï€2\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}. Thus using the same rationalizing transformationÂ (6.4) that we used above for the S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) one obtains homogeneous solutions that are free of any algebraic elements. -\frac{b(1+b)^{1+u}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}-t\big{)}_{t}}{(1+2u)(-1+b)^{u}}\sum_{i=1}^{u}\frac{(-1+b)^{i}(1+b)^{-i}(-t)_{i}}{(i+t)!}-\frac{b(-1+b)^{1+u}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}-t\big{)}_{t}}{(1+2u)(1+b)^{u}}\sum_{i=1}^{u}\frac{(-1+b)^{-i}(1+b)^{i}(-t)_{i}}{(i+t)!}  Denoting the result in Out[6.1] by Tâ€²â€‹(t,u)T^{\prime}(t,u) we obtain Finally, applying the substitutionÂ (6.5) to the right-hand side ofÂ (6.8) yields the simplification of S3â€‹(t)S_{3}(t) that has been used to perform
the estimateÂ (4.30) stated in LemmaÂ 4.10; for further details we refer to SectionÂ 6.2. To our knowledge this is the first time that rationalizing transformations, usually applied to simplify integrals, have been applied non-trivially to symbolic summation. As pointed out, in our concrete calculations such transformations can be discovered automatically when one looks for â€œniceâ€ hypergeometric solutions and sum solutions over such products of a given linear recurrence. It would be interesting to see where this extra feature could be also exploited in other applications.
